text: hi everyone
Anthony Fantino here Internet's busiest
music nerd and it's time for a review of
Montreal paralytic stalks of Montreal is
a jojoba and this is their 11th
full-length LP and they're one of those
sage indie acts that have been really
interesting to follow over the years
through all the highs and through all
the lows they started in the 90s sort of
as a part of the elephant six collective
which churned out some really great acts
like elf power apples and stereo olivia
tremor control the Neutral Milk Hotel 's
and their early stuff not to go on too
long about it was pretty much an
assembly of acoustic and psychedelic pop
tunes that were just proud to wear its
Beatles influences but of Montreal later
progressed into a sound that
incorporated more electronics more beats
more synthesizers and also started
bringing in sounds from glam rock and
funk music to thankfully over the course
of this change of Montreal did not just
become you know a blend in the
electronic act and part of the reason
they stayed interesting is because of
the singing and the songwriting from
frontman Kevin Barnes along with the
music his personality kind of changed
too in his songs he used to be pretty
kind of shy and introverted and throw
out a lot of quirky lyrics but alva out
on of Montreal's more recent stuff he
feels much more frantic and overly
emotional it's a persona that he
continues on this LP especially on
tracks like dour percentage where his
vocals are just so wild just lashing out
at anybody who will listen the lyrics
themselves are pretty raw and personal
sort of self-hating
sometimes Kevin Barnes is definitely his
own worst critic which is always
made of Montreal's dynamic kind of
interesting because you have these kind
of tortured painful lyrics being spewed
out over this music that is just too
sugary for words now on paralytic stalks
the music playing underneath barns
vocals is changing again and it's going
in a direction that I actually like more
honestly it seems to be passing more on
the electronics on the beats on the
synths it doesn't completely get rid of
them this album is not completely devoid
of that stuff especially on the intro to
year Anu the plaintiff or the end we
will commit Wolff murder but the role
the electronics play on this album is
noticeably smaller and these sounds are
being replaced with with arranged
instrumentation with strings with horns
with woodwinds and piano and to me it
gives of Montreal's usual eccentric and
kind of schizophrenic personality a sort
of refinement you know it doesn't feel
as gaudy it doesn't feel too
over-the-top the band still able to keep
up its energy though most of the time
because if there has been one other
noticeable change that came with the
electronics with the beats of Montreal's
music became really groove heavy and
that momentum is still here it's just
that with the arrangements with the
guitar the drums the bass all this live
instrumentation this instrumentation
that just just feels alive the energy is
just different more natural I think like
toward the end of the first half of year
anew the plaintiff we're of Montreal
kind of goes in this psychedelic rock
jam that gets pretty sweaty another
thing of Montreal keeps up with this LP
despite the sound change is the musical
density and detail that usually goes
into its albums there are so many sounds
bouncing back and forth on these tracks
if you put a pair of headphones on it
will play pong with your brain a lot of
tracks here just go through these really
quick fun and and almost unpredictable
evolutions a lot like the song winter
debts with all the changes on
tract it just feels like a song straight
off of the white album or Abbey Road or
something it starts off with this kind
of acoustic introduction that is really
kind of somber and then it goes into
these rushes of pianos eventually
there's this pit orchestra swelling
really ominously there's a spot in here
that sounds kind of country - with this
pedal steel playing and a and a sort of
honky-tonk piano in a way it kind of
reminds me of old of Montreal albums and
some stencil where there's a lot of
sound play I would call it a rehash of
old ideas but this album just feels too
big instrumentally to just say of
montreal has taken a step backwards
there are other tracks on here that go
through equally jarring changes that end
up stringing these songs out to seven
minutes eight minutes the final track is
13 minutes so a lot of these tracks rely
on either progressive or just really
unconventional song structures which
makes listening to these tracks kind of
like just driving really fast down a
winding road between the instrumentation
the longer tracks there's definitely
some shade of evolution going on with
this LP but of Montreal's changes have
always come slowly a lot like the album
satanic panic in the Attic is kind of a
foreshadowing of what was to happen on
hissing fauna are you the destroyer and
maybe paralytic stalks will be the
launchpad for the next new interesting
sound that of montreal plays with for a
handful of albums the band is
experimenting with avant-garde music
like on the eighth track here which is a
number nine style sound collage that
goes on for eight minutes and features a
plethora of sounds including the
instrumentation that I just mentioned
and some spoken word I think a lot of
the new fans especially the people who
love this groups poppier albums might
think that track is kind of boring but I
dug it I thought it was intense but
still even though if Montreal is clearly
experimenting on a lot of these tracks
their sweet side is still intact
again that tracked our percentage
which has a groove that reminds me a lot
of just disco music the vocals and
lyrics add that bittersweet touch to the
song and the saxophone solo off the back
end of that track is just sassy and the
song Malevich dowry is this acoustic
tune that I can't quite make heads or
tails of yet it feels like as soon as
that song rolls into town I'm just on an
island and I have a little coconut drink
or something it just feels really light
and sunny and kind of cute now there are
some issues I have with this LP and I'm
hoping that if of montreal continues
with this sound they hammer them out in
future albums of montreal is making a
lot of their songs longer now and in
order to do that they're adding more
parts to their songs and on some of
these tracks these parts flow together
really well on others they don't or the
other parts just kind of feel like
they're there the song winter debts
feels like a complete journey and I
really like how he renew the plaintive
starts off with these electronic beats
and through one transition after another
just blows into this full-on rock song
that really just is just awe-inspiring
to me how that track changes the final
track a lot like winter dets has a pop
tune at its start a string break and
then a piano ballad toward the end but I
do think it relies on this string
interlude in the middle a little too
much and while I'm complaining
I wasn't that huge on the first track it
was kind of heavy psychedelic and hazy
but just not all that memorable for me
and overall I guess I wish this album
was as conceptual as other of Montreal
albums that I love and if there is a
concept going on with this thing it has
not really revealed itself to me yet as
far as the lyrics and the stories on
this LP go it's a lot of the same stuff
Kevin Barnes has been singing about on
his past several albums and he knows
that he even brings it up in the second
track of the LP where he says lately all
I can produce his psychotic vitriol that
really should fill me with
and you know it's it's kind of
interesting to see that extra layer of
self-awareness get just placed on top of
this album but I think the lyrics are
are kind of due for a change just like
the the music is and that change is
happening here
with this record I think you get a lot
of solid pop tunes some nice
experimentation some progressive song
structures classier instrumentation some
great Arrangements written for that
classy instrumentation and the assurance
that of Montreal is not going anywhere
this is definitely the most fun I've had
listening to a new of Montreal album in
a while but what do I know
I didn't even really dig hissing fauna
as much as most people did I'm feeling a
decent strong seven on this LP what did
you guys think of it did you love it did
